item.title: U.S. Sees Opportunity for Ukraine to Capitalize on Russian Weakness
item.description: The next six weeks, before fall mud spreads, could allow Ukraine’s military to press forward in the Donbas and potentially retake Kherson, American officials said. But Russia may not be deterred.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military analysts say that Ukrainian forces have momentum on their side.

item.title: How Finnair’s Huge Bet on Faster Flights to Asia Suddenly Came Undone
item.description: When Russia closed its airspace, it upended the decades-long strategy for making Finland a European travel hub to and from the East.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Juho Kuva
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Juho Kuva for The New York Times

item.title: With Midterms Looming, Biden Isn’t Attending Big Campaign Rallies
item.description: President Biden’s low profile on the campaign trail reflects a low approval rating that makes him unwelcome in some congressional districts and states at a pivotal moment before the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Katie Glueck and Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has not held a campaign rally since before Labor Day.

item.title: Walker Says He Has ‘Overcome’ Mental Illness, but It’s Not So Simple, Experts Say
item.description: Most patients manage dissociative identity disorder, according to experts, rather than cure it. Herschel Walker, the G.O.P. Senate candidate in Georgia, says he has been “healed.”
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A watch party in Atlanta for the debate with Herschel Walker and Senator Raphael Warnock this month.

item.title: Ahead of the Midterms, Energy Lobbyists Plan for a Republican House
item.description: The oil and gas industry is already setting priorities for at least partial G.O.P. control in Congress, with a particular focus on undercutting a Biden administration program to shift away from gas for home heating.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Capitol Power Plant in Washington, D.C. Energy lobbyists are preparing for the possibility of Republicans taking control of the House, and are taking aim in particular at a Biden administration program encouraging a shift from natural gas to electricity for home heating.

item.title: Searching for Justice, 35 Years After Katricia Dotson Was Killed by the Police
item.description: Katricia Dotson’s remains were studied, disputed, displayed and litigated. Lost in the controversy was the life of an American girl and her family.
item.dc:creator: Bronwen Dickey

item.title: Your Paycheck Next Year Will Be Affected by Inflation. Here’s How.
item.description: If you get a raise, you may not end up in a higher tax bracket. But more of your income may be subject to Social Security taxes. And you’ll probably pay more for health care.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Food inflation in the United States has remained stubbornly high this year.

item.title: How Taiwan’s ‘Adorable’ and Ambitious Diplomacy Aims to Keep the Island Safe
item.description: Even as China’s threats on reunification grow more pointed, most recently at the Communist Party congress, Taiwan is working creatively to bolster its alliances.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese flags at Taiwan’s National Day celebrations in Taoyuan, Taiwan, this month.

item.title: In Los Angeles, Politics Are More Complex Than a Racist Recording Indicates
item.description: Recently leaked audio of Latino leaders exposed their ambition to gain power. But loyalties don’t always follow racial lines in the city’s most Latino district.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll, Shawn Hubler and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Tracy Nguyen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before it burned in the 1992 riots, a Black-owned barbershop stood on this corner in South Los Angeles. Today it’s a Latino-owned market that serves a changed neighborhood.

item.title: Judge Says Trump Signed Statement With Data His Lawyers Told Him Was False
item.description: The determination came in a decision by a federal judge that John Eastman, a lawyer for the former president, had to turn more of his emails over to the House Jan. 6 committee.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Mandel Ngan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The House committee investigating Jan. 6 views John Eastman as the intellectual architect of plans to subvert the 2020 election.

item.title: How the Emerald Ash Borer Took Ash Bats Out of Major League Baseball
item.description: Invasive insects and batter preferences have led to the elimination of the wood that dominated the sport for generations. There may not be a single ash bat used in this postseason.
item.dc:creator: Zach Schonbrun
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Babe Ruth was known for swinging an extra-large ash bat in his years of domination with the Yankees.

item.title: ALCS: Justin Verlander Dominates for Astros in Win Over Yankees
item.description: Justin Verlander struck out 11 batters and Houston beat up on the Yankees’ bullpen in a convincing Game 1 victory.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Houston’s Justin Verlander allowed one run in six innings of work. He struck out 11 and walked one.

item.title: NLCS: Big Inning Gives Padres Win Over Phillies in Game 2
item.description: A wild fifth inning turned a two-run deficit into a three-run lead, letting San Diego salvage a split before the series heads to Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Harry How/Getty Images
item.media:description: San Diego’s Brandon Drury gave the Padres a lead with a two-run double in the bottom of the fifth inning during Wednesday’s Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.

item.title: Politician, Thy Name Is Hypocrite
item.description: A rape-or-incest exception to anti-abortion laws isn’t humanitarian. It’s a meaningless rhetorical ploy.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Ross D. Franklin/Associated Press

item.title: A Good Faith Examination of Bad Faith
item.description: What can “The Rhetoric of Reaction” still teach us? A lot, it turns out.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada
item.media:credit: Mike Haddad

item.title: The Battle Between Pocketbooks and Principles
item.description: Incandescent rage, however brightly it burns at the start, has a tendency to dim.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: A Town With a Heart, but Few Options, for Migrants
item.description: It’s fruitless to lecture El Paso about the hardship of receiving buses. The government sent it hundreds upon hundreds of people every day.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Stack
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Margelis Polo Negrette, 9, getting a hand from a Customs and Border Protection officer after she and her parents, Marielith Negrette and Eduardo Polo Diaz, crossed the Rio Grande into El Paso in early October, a few days before a policy change that would have barred them from the country.

item.title: No, Capitalism and the Internet Will Not Free China’s People
item.description: The Communist Party’s war on independent thought continues.
item.dc:creator: Ai Weiwei
item.media:credit: Elaine

item.title: What the World Will Lose if Ancient Trees Die Out
item.description: Old trees engage our deepest faculties: to revere, analyze and meditate.
item.dc:creator: Jared Farmer
item.media:credit: Rachel Sussman

item.title: We Advised Biden on the Pandemic. Much Work Remains to Face the Next Crisis.
item.description: Even with the successes against Covid, there is much room for improvement.
item.dc:creator: Ezekiel J. Emanuel, David Michaels, Rick Bright and Michael T. Osterholm
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: George Wylesol

item.title: If the Federal Reserve Were a Car Dealership …
item.description: How to sell the American public on a questionable vehicle.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images via Getty Images

item.title: The State of the Midterms
item.description: The midterm elections are less than three weeks away. We explain the state of the races for the House and Senate.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times

item.title: Why Republicans Are Winning Swing Voters
item.description: The G.O.P. is gaining an edge in midterm elections that will determine control of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Sydney Harper, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mail-in ballots in Phoenix. Polling suggests that Republicans enter the final weeks of the contest for control of Congress with a narrow but distinct advantage.

item.title: The 2022 Midterms: Is Wisconsin the Future of America?
item.description: In Wisconsin, aggressive and methodical gerrymandering has allowed Republicans to cement their political power. Can Democrats ever make inroads?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: ilbusca/ Getty Images

item.title: Affordable Oysters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking for the best happy hour deals with quality food? We have recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Shukette in Chelsea, the Middle Eastern menu’s selection of oven-fired breads, richly spiced vegetables and seafood, and dips lends itself handsomely to group dining.

item.title: A Shrinking Town at the Center of France’s Culture Wars
item.description: A plan to revitalize the town of Callac by bringing in skilled immigrants has divided it and made it an emblem of a nation’s anxiety over its identity and decline.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim Zakaria Youssouf, originally from Sudan, with his wife, Mariam Hissein Abderamam, outside their home in Callac, France, where they have been living for two years.

item.title: Times Square May Get One of the Few Spectacles It Lacks: A Casino
item.description: The battle to win a New York City casino license has heated up in Manhattan, with real estate and gambling giants offering competing proposals for Times Square and Hudson Yards.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein, Nicole Hong and Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new proposal for a Times Square casino already faces opposition from the Broadway League, a trade association representing theater owners and producers.

item.title: A Federal Reserve President Spoke at an Invite-Only, Off-Record Bank Client Event
item.description: James Bullard, who leads the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, appeared at a Citigroup forum last week in Washington. Reporters were not invited.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis

item.title: Webb Telescope Captures New View of ‘Pillars of Creation’
item.description: The NASA space observatory’s infrared eye finds out what’s going on within the cloudy cosmic nursery.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: NASA
item.media:description: “Pillars of Creation” captured in NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope’s near-infrared view. The pillars resemble arches and spires rising from a desert, but are filled with semitransparent gas and dust.

item.title: Quitting Smoking: Can E-Cigarettes Help?
item.description: Here’s what the evidence suggests.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Neti Pots and How Do They Work?
item.description: Nasal rinsing has been used for thousands of years to relieve sinus inflammation, congestion, allergy symptoms and more. Here’s what the evidence says.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Tyler Comrie

item.title: How Many Close Friends Do You Need in Adulthood?
item.description: Social circles were shrinking even before the pandemic. Here’s what the science says about the number of close friendships we should have.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Nathalie Lees

item.title: Grind Your Teeth? Your Night Guard May Not Be the Right Fix
item.description: Some experts say tooth-grinding is a behavior rather than a disorder, and the dentist’s chair isn’t the best place to address it.
item.dc:creator: Kate Murphy
item.media:credit: Jon Han

item.title: Review: Seven Dancers Step Into the Rhythm of a Moroccan Night
item.description: The choreographer Fouad Boussouf presents his mystical “Näss” at the Joyce Theater as part of the Crossing the Line Festival.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:credit: Andrea Mohin/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left Loïc Elice, Sami Blond and Justin Gouin.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
